source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_033_chunk3
evidence_span: Conversions to Standard Hydrogen Electrode Potential—To enable comparison of hightemperature and low-temperature electrochemical data, the measured values are converted to the standard hydrogen electrode (SHE) scale. First, a term is added to adjust for temperature. The value of 0.109 [15] was used in the high-temperature measurements.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_033_chunk3
evidence_span: At $2 5 \mathrm { ^ \circ C }$ this potential shift $\Delta E$ is calculated to be $0 . 3 2 5 \mathrm { ~ V ~ }$ .

evidence_span: Using a $p k W$ of 11.2 at $2 5 0 \mathrm { { } ^ { \circ } C }$ (523 K) [16], a $\mathsf { p H }$ shift from 5.5 to 4.4 is calculated.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_033_chunk5
evidence_span: At 25°C. the rest potentials for both zirconium and Zircaloys are below the equilibrium potential for the standard hydrogen electrode, SHE. at pH 5.5 and for pH2 = 1 bar.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_033_chunk5
evidence_span: The rest potentials of the intermetallics are more noble than the SHE.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_033_chunk5
evidence_span: At 250°C the range of potentials is narrower, yet the intermetallics are still more noble than the Zircaloy metal matrix.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_033_chunk5
evidence_span: The effect of coupling the zirconium alloy matrix to the intermetallic alloy at 25°C was demonstrated experimentally

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_033_chunk5
evidence_span: As the relative area of intermetallic increases, the potential becomes more noble. Conversely, increasing the zirconium substrate area results in more active potentials.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_033_chunk5
evidence_span: Rp values from potentiodynamic tests were reported in Table 5. Indeed, the Zircaloy system is under anodic control. Relative Rp values are 143, 0.5, 6.8, and 2.1 MΩ/cm2 for Zr X bar, Zr2Fe, Zr(Fe,Cr)2 and Zr2(Fe,Ni).

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_033_chunk5
evidence_span: Rp values from potentiodynamic tests were reported in Table 5. Indeed, the Zircaloy system is under anodic control. Relative Rp values are 143, 0.5, 6.8, and 2.1 MΩ/cm2 for Zr X bar, Zr2Fe, Zr(Fe,Cr)2 and Zr2(Fe,Ni).

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_033_chunk5
evidence_span: Rp values from potentiodynamic tests were reported in Table 5. Indeed, the Zircaloy system is under anodic control. Relative Rp values are 143, 0.5, 6.8, and 2.1 MΩ/cm2 for Zr X bar, Zr2Fe, Zr(Fe,Cr)2 and Zr2(Fe,Ni).

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_033_chunk5
evidence_span: Rp values from potentiodynamic tests were reported in Table 5. Indeed, the Zircaloy system is under anodic control. Relative Rp values are 143, 0.5, 6.8, and 2.1 MΩ/cm2 for Zr X bar, Zr2Fe, Zr(Fe,Cr)2 and Zr2(Fe,Ni).

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_033_chunk5
evidence_span: Weight gain data performed in steam help explain the role intermetallics play in the development on the oxide film. The higher relative weight gain of the intermetallics suggest that, when the intermetallic particles are incorporated into the growing oxide layer and are electrically isolated from the metal substrate, they will oxidize and or break up.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_033_chunk5
evidence_span: However, it can be expected, when intermetallic particles serve as cathodic sites. that they are protected at the expense of the surrounding Zircaloy matrix.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_033_chunk6
evidence_span: Many nodule precursors were observed after exposure to $5 0 0 \mathrm { { } ^ { \circ } C }$ steam on materials expected to have both good and poor nodule resistance.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_033_chunk6
evidence_span: The high density of intermetallic particles along the alpha-grain boundaries, typical of material quenched from the alpha $^ +$ beta zone, lowers the susceptibility of nodular corrosion by blocking or redirecting surface oxide cracks.
specimen_state: material quenched from the alpha+beta zone

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_033_chunk6
evidence_span: The finely dispersed intermetallic structure characteristic of Zircaloy, which has been beta-quenched late in processing, lowers nodule formation by increasing the precursor site density, thus distributing the stress fields more uniformly.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_033_chunk6
evidence_span: The larger size and randomly distributed intermetallic structure typical of material receiving final anneal(s) in the alpha zone is the least efficient in stopping nodule growth.
specimen_state: material receiving final anneal(s) in the alpha zone

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_033_chunk7
evidence_span: The fine distribution. however. also increases the available cathodic sites, which tends to increase the overall oxidation rate

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_033_chunk7
evidence_span: beta-quenched material typically has a higher uniform oxidation rate in PWRs

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_033_chunk7
evidence_span: beta-quenched material typically has a higher weight gain before nodules are visible in BWRs

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_033_chunk7
evidence_span: the fine distribution of intermetallic particles, which exists for the beta-quenched material, offers many cathodic sites and, in addition, lowers the mean distance from the active anodic ring to the cathodic particle

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_033_chunk7
evidence_span: This enhancement results in higher oxidation rates for late beta-quenched material in PWRs

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_033_chunk7
evidence_span: the material that was beta-quenched earlier in the processing schedule have fewer, coarser intermetallic particles, which provide fewer cathodic sites and longer mean distances from the anodic ring to the cathodic site

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_033_chunk7
evidence_span: This situation limits the anodic oxidation and results in lower uniform corrosion rates

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_033_chunk7
evidence_span: the observance of nodules in both BWR environments and in >450°C steam autoclaves

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_033_chunk7
evidence_span: intermetallic compositions are more noble than the surrounding zirconium metal substrate

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_033_chunk7
evidence_span: intermetallic compounds serve as cathodic reaction sites in the anodic oxidation of the Zircaloy substrate

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_033_chunk7
evidence_span: intermetallic compounds to have a higher weight gain per mass of specimen exposed as expressed in percent weight gain

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_033_chunk8
evidence_span: Nodules that form in steam nucleate instead at areas high induced stress.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_033_chunk8
evidence_span: Figures 7 and 8 show nucleation sites as small as $2 \mu \mathrm { m }$ diameter.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_033_chunk8
evidence_span: The autoclave was purged with argon typically for 12 to $1 6 \mathrm { ~ h ~ }$

evidence_span: The voltmeters all had input impedances greater than $1 0 \ \mathbf { M } \Omega$

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_033_chunk8
evidence_span: Experimental corrosion data are collected from a great number of rods taken from seven different power reactors, from the CIRENE out-of-pile loop, and from autoclave tests.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_033_chunk8
evidence_span: Metallographic examinations of SRA Zircaloy-4 tubings constitute the experimental data

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_033_chunk8
evidence_span: Measurements give an idea of the waterside corrosion behavior of Zircaloy-4 for the following encountered operating conditions in French or foreign reactors: One to four cycles of irradiation in 900 MWe PWRs.
